I am the sea captain navigating the treacherous waters of illegal shark finning. 

Those bleeding hearts in the media can bleat all they want about "cruelty" and "endangered species."  They don't understand the real world. This ain't some nature documentary; this is about putting food on the table and making a living. Shark fin soup is a delicacy, a status symbol. There's a huge market out there, and I'm filling the demand.  

We keep a low profile, of course. No fancy boats, no bragging. We work under the radar, stick to international waters, and make sure our shipments are well-hidden.  And when those do-gooders start poking around, we deny everything. We're just honest fishermen, they say, catching what we can to survive. 

The truth is, these sharks are practically swimming money. Their fins fetch a high price, and the rest of the carcass? Well, there are ways to dispose of that without raising too many eyebrows. It's all about being smart, being discreet, and knowing the right people.  The media can keep crying foul, but they can't stop the tide of progress. The demand is there, and someone's gotta supply it. Might as well be me.

Encourage consumers to avoid products containing shark fins. Promote awareness campaigns and educate the public about the ethical and environmental consequences of shark fin consumption.

Work with governments, NGOs, fishing communities, and businesses to develop sustainable solutions. Foster partnerships and dialogue to find common ground.
